Article.Abstract: Vaccine development in animal models depends on ability to recognize epitopes seen by human T cells. In this work, we show that CTL responses in transgenic mice expressing human HLA-A2.1 prospectively predict the same four of 11 hepatitis C virus (HCV) structural protein-derived peptides, expressing a sequence motif for HLA-A2.1 binding, that are actually recognized by human A2.1-restricted CTLs. The CTLs also recognized targets endogenously expressing these proteins. Human CTLs from HCV-infected patients, tested by using the same peptides, revealed a virtually identical response repertoire. A highly conserved HCV core peptide was the most immunogenic, and may be a valuable component of a vaccine against a broad range of HCV isolates in HLA-A2-positive patients. These results suggest that, in spite of species differences, the T cell repertoire is plastic enough to allow a similar response when the same class I MHC molecule is presenting the peptide. Thus, the HLA molecule plays the primary role in determining which peptides are recognized by CTLs. This transgenic mouse model is important for the study of HLA-restricted CTL determinants and for an approach to design a potential HCV vaccine.
Article.ArticleTitle: CTL responses of HLA-A2.1-transgenic mice specific for hepatitis C viral peptides predict epitopes for CTL of humans carrying HLA-A2.1.
Article.Affiliations: Third Department of Internal Medicine, Kagawa Medical School, Japan.
Article.ArticleChemicalList: Antigens, Viral;Epitopes;HLA-A2 Antigen;Hepatitis C Antigens;Receptors, Antigen, T-Cell;Recombinant Proteins

Article.Comments: Data originally imported from the Database of Functional Molecular Immunology, FIMM (http://sdmc.lit.org.sg:8080/fimm/)

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were infected with recombinant vaccinia virus expressing hepatitis C core and envelope proteins. CTL were generated through in vitro restimulation of splenocytes with the epitope, Jurkat-A2/Kb cells, and ConA prior to assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Epitope specific CTL cells lysed Jurkat-A2/Kb cells infected with recombinant vaccinia virus expressing hepatitis C core and envelope proteins.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were infected with recombinant vaccinia virus expressing hepatitis C core and envelope proteins. CTL were generated through in vitro restimulation of splenocytes with the epitope, Jurkat-A2/Kb cells, and ConA prior to assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CTL cells from HLA-A2.1 mice infected with recombinant vaccinia virus expressing hepatitis C core and envelope proteins lysed Jurkat-A2/Kb and C1R-A2.1 target cells presenting the epitope. The response was blocked by anti-CD8 antibody.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBL were isolated from patients infected with hepatitis C virus, confirmed by the presence of HCV-specific antibody. CTL were generated through in vitro restimulation of peripheral blood leukocytes with the epitope and IL-2 prior to assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CTL cells from Hepatitis C infected patients lysed C1R-A2.1 cells presenting the epitope. Class I restriction was demonstrated through the use of blocking antibody.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: The following refers to the epitope id as found in the original FIMM database: P000050.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBL were isolated from patients infected with hepatitis C virus, confirmed by the presence of HCV-specific antibody. CTL were generated through in vitro restimulation of peripheral blood leukocytes with the epitope and IL-2 prior to assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CTL cells from Hepatitis C infected patients did not lyse C1R-A2.1 cells presenting the epitope.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were infected with recombinant vaccinia virus expressing hepatitis C core and envelope proteins. CTL were generated through in vitro restimulation of splenocytes with the epitope, Jurkat-A2/Kb cells, and ConA prior to assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CTL cells from HLA-A2.1 mice infected with recombinant vaccinia virus expressing hepatitis C core and envelope proteins exhibited a low level of lysis of Jurkat-A2/Kb and C1R-A2.1 target cells presenting the epitope.
